summary: Nicholas B. Stevenson was a Sergeant in the USAF. He was interviewed by the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) in 1978 regarding allegations made by David F. Christensen concerning President Kennedy's assassination. The interview focused on Stevenson's recollections of events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland, a facility able to collect the Lisbon-Tangier link. Following the interview, Julia Wetzel from the NSA visited the HSCA to review a report by Cornwell and Klein regarding their interview with Stevenson and ensured its classification as "CONFIDENTIAL, HANDLE VIA COMINT CHANNELS ONLY."
significance: Nicholas B. Stevenson's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his involvement with USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland, and his interview with the HSCA regarding allegations made by David F. Christensen. His recollections of events at this facility, which was capable of collecting the Lisbon-Tangier link, were deemed sensitive enough to warrant classification by the NSA, suggesting a potential connection to intelligence activities relevant to the assassination investigation.
